text: (intriguing music)
- Hi, Bryan.

First of all, thanks for
taking the time to talk to me

about all things around
cloud and generative AI.

So let me start off with maybe
can you tell me a little bit

about INRIX and what is
your role at the company?
- Sure, so I'm the co-founder and CEO.
INRIX has been around for about 20 years

and we're the leading provider
of transportation information
and analytics globally.

So we supply information
to public sector agencies
and governments, to enterprise customers,
including folks like Amazon Logistics

and other customers that
are looking to figure out
how to optimize transportation networks.

- Can you share, I mean
clearly, you've been driving
this vision and the company for a while.

So what role does cloud
and particularly AWS play

in data and machine learning
and gen AI strategy as well?

- Yeah, sure, so 20 years
ago, there was no cloud,

so we started building
our own data centers.

- Yeah.
- And very quickly realized
it was a huge cost, very inflexible
and required a lot of investment.

So when cloud computing
and AWS got off the ground,
we were one of the first customers

to start moving all of
our services to the cloud,

and today everything runs
in the AWS environment.

AI, we started and launched
our first AI product

about seven years ago when we
were using machine learning

and AI to analyze data coming
in from around the world

to help figure out what
was really going on
on the transportation networks.
So, you know, we couldn't be bigger fans

of both AWS as well as AI
and the power to analyze

incredible amounts of
information very quickly.

- And what are the examples
of like how you leveraged
machine learning or AI seven years ago?

Is it to do things like root
cause analysis or forecasting?
Or can you share a little bit more?

- Yeah, for us it was
really trying to understand
if we're seeing, for instance,
you know, absence of traffic on a bridge.
Why is that?
Is that because the bridge closed?
Is it construction?
Is it bad weather?
Is it something else?

So for us it was really
helping us understand
on every roadway around the world

when something abnormal
happened, what was causing it.

That really is one of the
key ingredients for us
in terms of how AI added a lot of value.
- You were able to accomplish that

by actually combining various
different data sources

and then actually using
that to get to a conclusion

on what was likely root cause
and what to do about it.
- Yeah, exactly.
So we have, you know, 20 years,
50 petabytes of transportation data.
So we're very good at understanding,

you know, historical patterns
and what should be happening.

And then this massive amount
of real-time information
of more than 600 different data feeds

from commercial vehicles,
consumer vehicles,

parking sensors, all sorts
of things that we look at.
So again, the question is how can you look
through all that information?

You can't do it manually,
it has to be automated.
So for us, understanding, like you said,
where there's abnormalities.

Is it a big storm coming in
that's shutting down freeways?
Is it a protest?
There's a lot of signal that you can get,
but ferreting out what the root causes are
for us was really key.
- Oh, that's exciting.
Okay, I completely get it.
So it's actually just trying to identify,

signal out a huge amount
of data and then knowing
is that gonna be actually a big pattern
that is emerging and so forth.

That totally makes sense.
- Yep.
- Now fast forwarding seven years
from seven years ago to now

in a world where generative
AI has really become
like core conversation

and many of our core
IT strategy altogether.
So I know our teams are working together
to solve some of this.
Maybe can you share a little bit more

on what are some of the top
challenges related to AI

that you have been able to
solve with Amazon Bedrock?
- Yeah, sure.
So we were an early adopter.

We launched our first Bedrock
implementation in November,
actually at AWS re:Invent.

And it's really enabled
us to do two things
we couldn't do before.

One was really better
understanding causality.
So you know, again, if there's a slowdown,

for us, we have a lot of
information in our data lake.
Things like safety information,
things like parking information,
things like commute and trip patterns,
real-time traffic, events.

So the question was again,
when something's happening,

what's the root cause of
it and can you fare it out,

you know, which database to
go look for to figure out
what the impact will be?
So it's not just understanding root cause,

now we're moving into
really prescription, right?
What's happening?

I know what that is, what
should I do about it?

But that also involves
going through literally
tens of thousands of government reports.

There's these before and
after studies, right?
Add a roundabout.
What did it look like before

in terms of safety and
accidents and speed?
What did it look like after?
So if you've got 50, 60,000 reports,

there's no human being
who's gonna take that,
type it into a database.
What we need is the ability for AI

to crawl through all the
government information
to better understand if this is a problem,
what can I do about it?

And then if I implement it,
what will the impact be?

Well, I see a 7%, 8%, 15%
reduction in fatalities,

then I'll go ahead and
make the investment.
So those are the type of things
that we've really deployed our AI around,
a product we launched called AI Compass

that allows state department
of transportations and cities
to take advantage of this data
and query it in a very easy way.

Step one is figure out
what the root cause is.

Step two then is okay,
if that's the root cause,

well, I wanna look at
every city around the world

and I wanna look at similar
intersection designs.

What can be done to improve
intersection designs?
That's number two.

And then number three is, okay,
if I now decide I need to go

add signage or add a new
stoplight or something like that,

what can I expect in terms
of overall improvement?
So those are sort of the key three areas

that transportation engineers
and planners look at.

The last two of those,
we weren't able to do
up until very recently with generative AI.

- That is actually such
a really innovative use
of generative AI.

So I would love to double click
a little bit on that example
and talk about the customer experience.

In this scenario, is the
customer of your Compass

like a transportation planner
in the state department

who interacts with the
data and then figures out
and uses that reasoning capabilities

with the Bedrock models
and be able to generate it?
Is that really how it works
from a customer experience perspective?

- Yeah, exactly. Let's
take a real-time example.
So Caltrans,

which is the California
Department of Transportation,
recently awarded a project to us
and it's really looking at road safety.

So, we can look at, you know,
safety problems on the road,

where there's fatalities,
where there's accidents,

and then start to ask, is
it because of speeding?
Is it because of hard braking?
Is it because of, you know,
different people can't see each other,
visibility, those type of things?
So there's a lot of causes for that.

And what they want their
transportation planners
to be able to do is query the data, right?
Be able to ask questions, right?

We have applications that
allow cities and states

to look at safety, but in order
to sort of really understand
what the root causes are,

they wanna be able to
ask different questions,
like they were interviewing an expert.

That's part one of what
generative AI allows us to do.

And then part two is for us
to take all of the manuals
and documents and things

that the Department of
Transportation has created
about, you know, recommended solutions
to different problems, load that in

so that California can
basically not only have

access to what's causing it,
but their own recommendations,

their own documentation
and all of that crawled

so that we can give
prescriptions that are in line
with their overall, you know, policy.

So, that's really the core
focus of what we're doing
with Caltrans is just one example.
- As a builder who is actually building
some of these remarkable experiences,

I mean, there are so
many models that exist,

people actually end up
putting together these models

to solve these problems
in a different way.
You chose to build on top of Bedrock.

Can you give some why
did you choose Bedrock
and what models did you use?

Can you share some of
these insights as well?
- Sure, so the big advantage for us
in looking at Amazon Bedrock and using it
is it does give us model choice.

And what we found is there
is not one right model
for everything, right?

So, you know, a lot of
information is data,

so how do you crawl through
data and analyze it?
What we found is Claude 2.1 and Claude 3

were really the two best
models that we've seen.

And we were able to test
a dozen different models.
I think eight of those were at AWS,
several were outside of AWS,
to really come to the conclusion
of which one gave us the best answers.

And then what we found is now
we're looking at other models

for how do we crawl
through these documents

and come up with the best
generative responses.
So the thing we like about Bedrock is

it makes it very easy to
test against different models

and see which model is best
for different types of problems
that we have to solve.
That for us was the big advantage.

That and of course,
our data lake is at AWS

so it makes it very easy for
us to point the models at,

you know, using RAG and
other implementations,
to be able to query the right databases
and get the right information back
very quickly and very easily

without having to move
a bunch of data around.

- That's actually, I mean,
so much of what you said
resonates so much because I end up saying

many of these things in
my own keynotes and talks

around model choice and data
being your differentiator
and marrying these two, so it feels like
what you said resonates so much with me.
Little bit on maybe one other question
on what are some of the tangible benefits

that you are seeing with
something like Bedrock
when it comes to like your business
or employees or customers.
Is it actually like faster time to market,
or more productivity from developers?

I'm trying to understand
like what is possible now

that wasn't before and any
quantifiable metrics that,
if you have any to share?
- Well, for us, I think it's two things.
One is yes, time to market really matters.

You know, as you know,
generative AI hasn't been around

all that long and it's
evolving very, very quickly.

So for us to be able to test
against different models,
bring features to market very quickly,

you know, in a matter of,
you know, a month, six weeks,

eight weeks as opposed to,
you know, six months or a year
is really critical for us.
So time to market was first and foremost.
The second thing is,

and this is probably a
little bit less intuitive.

Again, we're not building
a chat bot, right?

What we're doing is we're
taking a massive data lake

and trying to crawl that
data lake and apply not just,

you know, textual responses,
but we wanna be able to pull up

for, you know, the right
graphic, the right image,
the right histogram for customers

when they're looking at,
you know, asking a question.
So for us, it's not just the model,

it's the integration with
the other AWS services
that is really important to us, right?

Obviously, you know, S3 and the
storage, you know, services,

but also some of the
other analytics services

that we make use of, being
able to tie that all together

very efficiently for us
allows us to build products
in, you know, weeks as opposed to months,
which for us is an important thing.
- That's very, very insightful.

And really actually,
when you talk about pace,

one thing that popped out,
I say this internally, is

there is regular pace
and there is gen AI pace

and time to market should
be in the matter of weeks.

And so many of the words
what you used is very similar

to what I actually tell,
not just to our customers,
but for internal teams as well,
so what you say resonates a lot.
That leads to my final question.

Now, for others who are
interested in generative AI
and also specifically gen AI on AWS,

what are actually two or three
things that you'll give us
your personal advice on their journey?
- Yeah, so first, you know,

unlike I think traditional
enterprise development,
I think everybody has to be aware
that everything you're developing now
will be thrown out in six months.

I mean, the technology
is just moving so fast.
You know, we've had several features
that we've tried to build ourselves
'cause they didn't exist,
and then AWS six months later announced
things like GovCloud, things like,

you know, Guardrails was a
very important one for us.
We don't want a model
to come up with answers or hallucinate.
We need it to look at our data.
So things like that, I think we all,
you know, need to recognize

that time to market is much
shorter, which is good,
but a lot of this may look different

and you need to be prepared
to kind of throw away,

you know, code six or
nine months down the line.

I think that the second
thing is really understand
what you're trying to do.

Again, we were very, I think,
clear from the beginning.
We didn't want a chat bot, right?

What we wanted is to
integrate the data lake.
And I think there's a long way to go in AI
to make it easy to do that.

Right now, there's a lot of
work around prompt engineering,
but though, let's be honest.
You know, people like us,
we don't really care about the prompt.
We just wanna stuff a bunch of data

or even better have the AI
model already understand
the design of our data lake
so that when a question is asked,
it knows where to go automatic

to get the answers to
those kind of questions.

So, you know, again,
so really understanding

what you want AI to do for
you, I think is pretty key.
And then the second is,
you know, we weren't afraid to experiment.
We were very fortunate 'cause the AWS team
hosted an internal hackathon with us
where we basically for a week,

we shut down our company and
they had all the employees,
you know, work on different teams
and come up with a bunch of ideas.

And we had, I think about
a dozen AWS employees

in the hallway for the week,
basically answering questions
and helping people come up with it.

So we had about, I think
40 teams and of those,

I think about 20 projects
has now gone into production.
So that kind of thing is super important

'cause you know, I don't
think we as executives
can dream up all the scenarios,

but I'm pretty sure that
having the entire company
at all the levels

think about how they can
use AI in their jobs,
they came up with much better ideas
than we ever would as a leadership team.

So really opening it up
to the entire company

and getting people to brainstorm
for us was super valuable.
- Those are really, really, I mean,

a great set of advices and
really tangible action items
that a bunch of our customers could take
and execute right away.

Hey, Bryan, thanks again
for actually taking the time

to share some of your
insights here with us

and your experiences with Bedrock
and generative AI as well.
I really learned a lot and really hoping
to build more amazing things together

and hopefully, traffic jams
are a thing of the past
in the future.
- (laughs) We hope so too.
Thank you for having me.
Appreciate it.
